name: (2E)-3-(3-Hydroxyphenyl)-2-(1-methyl-1H-benzimidazol-2-yl)acrylonitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1134

name: (2E)-3-(3-Hydroxyphenyl)-2-(1-methyl-1H-benzimidazol-2-yl)acrylonitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1134
Reason:
The basic unit for this prediction will be a simple aliphatic nitrile, which typically has a melting point range of around 0-5 degrees Celsius. The modifications from this basic structure will be as follows:
- Phenyl rings: Two phenyl rings are present. Each generally increases the melting point due to the aromatic system's stacking ability and π-π interactions, which might add around +50 degrees Celsius each.
- Hydroxy group: Hydroxyl groups can form hydrogen bonds, which significantly raise the melting point. This effect might be around +80 degrees Celsius.
- Benzimidazole group: This bicyclic entity can introduce rigidity and planar structure, promoting additional stacking interactions, possibly adding another +50 degrees Celsius.
- Acrylonitrile moiety: The presence of the cyano group linked to an alkene may increase the melting point moderately, let's approximate this at +20 degrees Celsius.
Adding these increments together gives us a predicted melting point: 0 (for the basic nitrile) + 50 (phenyl ring 1) + 50 (phenyl ring 2) + 80 (hydroxy group) + 50 (benzimidazole) + 20 (acrylonitrile) = 250 degrees Celsius.
